item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“javedman0208, post:29, topic:300914”]Very nice Super_
Writing the JNI can be a big headache, although smaller than writing everything in Java again. There are some code generators available which can generate the JNI layer for you. The most popular code generator is SWIG(Simplified Wrapper Interface Generator). SWIG is a software development tool that connects programs written in C and C++ with a variety of high-level programming languages. SWIG is used with different types of languages including common scripting languages such as Perl, PHP, Python, Tcl and Ruby. SWIG is driven via scripts which are read by SWIG and then converted into particular language interface.

Through JNI one can call C and C++ code from Java. JNI is the glue layer between (C,C++) and Java. JNI is not easy thing to do as it is hard to map (C, C++) and Java code. All Java data types does not have one to one mapping with their (C,C++)counterparts. Object orientation is bit different as well as Java does not support multi-inheritance. With Java you have GC(Garbage Collector), which does not exists on (C,C++), may be smarts pointers are there to achieve GC. Exceptions exists on both programming languages but they are handled differently. In C++, exceptions are not part of the language, where as exceptions are central to Java.
Basically to use C and C++ from Java you have write the shim JNI layer.[/quote]http://www.pakgamers.com/forums/software-game-development-programming/35460-jni-java-native-interface.html

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @javedman0208 javedman0208
item.description:
@javedman0208 wrote:

Very nice Super_
Writing the JNI can be a big headache, although smaller than writing everything in Java again. There are some code generators available which can generate the JNI layer for you. The most popular code generator is SWIG(Simplified Wrapper Interface Generator). SWIG is a software development tool that connects programs written in C and C++ with a variety of high-level programming languages. SWIG is used with different types of languages including common scripting languages such as Perl, PHP, Python, Tcl and Ruby. SWIG is driven via scripts which are read by SWIG and then converted into particular language interface.

Through JNI one can call C and C++ code from Java. JNI is the glue layer between (C,C++) and Java. JNI is not easy thing to do as it is hard to map (C, C++) and Java code. All Java data types does not have one to one mapping with their (C,C++)counterparts. Object orientation is bit different as well as Java does not support multi-inheritance. With Java you have GC(Garbage Collector), which does not exists on (C,C++), may be smarts pointers are there to achieve GC. Exceptions exists on both programming languages but they are handled differently. In C++, exceptions are not part of the language, where as exceptions are central to Java.
Basically to use C and C++ from Java you have write the shim JNI layer.

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

BLERGH. JNIInvokeInterface->AttachCurrentThread doesn’t work. Thread.start() calls JVM_StartThread() defined in jvm.h, an internal interface.

I’m not sure how you could hook that to hook JNIEnv calls. The JVMTI interface looks like a good place to start.

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Oh wait, I made a mistake :(, should have checked my code

There is only one JavaVM (although you get it from a array), which means you can access every object from whichever context.
The JNIEnv* is attached to the current thread and therefor hooking it is indeed not going to work that way

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

qauters:

Currently java supports only one JNIEnv for each jvm. So every native library has access to the same and also if you just inject a dll you also get the same. Pointers are process specific and therefor it gives no problem at all to use them

Great thank you.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 26, 2009, 11:53:20 pm[/size][hr]Are you sure? It seems like JNIEnv is thread specific and only valid for the current thread.
If so then you would have to hook every thread. A pain in the ass.

Edit: Hook JNIInvokeInterface. Hopefully a “new Thread().start()” call would require a call to JNIInvokeInterface->AttachCurrentThread().
Use GetJavaVM to get JNIInvokeInterface (a JavaVM) then set AttachCurrentThread to hook the returned JNIEnv.

Can anyone confirm that start() uses JNIInvokeInterface->AttachCurrentThread() ?

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:23, topic:300914”]A bump a month old but given recent activity on the board I don’t see it as a problem.

This is a great idea. One question: Is the same JNIEnv shared across all native code in the same JVM?

Obviously a new JVM would have its own JNIEnv which you would have to inject your code into. I’m a little hazy on how far pointers can go. Are they process specific or thread specific or can the JVM sandbox you so that if another piece of code calls JNIEnv->getVersion() it will attempt to access an illegal segment of memory belonging to your own library?

I’m sure your code can be improved a bit. Hard coding the index is ugly. I’m sure there is a way to access it by name but its been a while since I’ve done anything JNI or even C/C++ related.[/quote]
Currently java supports only one JNIEnv for each jvm. So every native library has access to the same and also if you just inject a dll you also get the same. Pointers are process specific and therefor it gives no problem at all to use them

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It doesn’t particularly matter that it’s “process specific” since they can’t keep you out of the process.

Read full topic

item.title: JNIEnv function hooking
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

A bump a month old but given recent activity on the board I don’t see it as a problem.

This is a great idea. One question: Is the same JNIEnv shared across all native code in the same JVM?

Obviously a new JVM would have its own JNIEnv which you would have to inject your code into. I’m a little hazy on how far pointers can go. Are they process specific or thread specific or can the JVM sandbox you so that if another piece of code calls JNIEnv->getVersion() it will attempt to access an illegal segment of memory belonging to your own library?

I’m sure your code can be improved a bit. Hard coding the index is ugly. I’m sure there is a way to access it by name but its been a while since I’ve done anything JNI or even C/C++ related.

Read full topic

@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:16, topic:300914”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=397198.msg2966740#msg2966740 date=1253648389]

Maybe JNI is like PHP, Php Hypertext Processor Jni Native Interface

That’s called recursion. Also its preprocessor, not processor.
[/quote]

PHP is a retronym.[/quote]
Zeev Suraski and Andi Gutmans, two developers at the Technion IIT, rewrote the parser in 1997 and formed the base of PHP 3, changing the language’s name to the recursive initialism PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor.[10]

Sauce: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PHP#History

GNU /ɡnuː/ ( listen) is an operating system and an extensive collection of computer software. GNU is composed wholly of free software, most of which is licensed under the GNU Project's own General Public License (GPL). GNU is a recursive acronym for "GNU's Not Unix!", chosen because GNU's design is Unix-like, but differs from Unix by being free software and containing no Unix code. The GNU project includes an operating system kernel, GNU HURD, which was the original focus of the Free Software Fo...
